questions.question: Infrastructure as a Service (IaaS) provides customers with:

options.A: Complete application software ready to use
options.B: Virtualized computing resources like servers, storage, and networking

questions.explanation: IaaS provides virtualized infrastructure—virtual machines, storage, networks—that customers manage. The provider manages the physical infrastructure. Customers install and manage their own operating systems and applications. Examples: AWS EC2, Azure VMs.
questions.tip: IaaS = virtual infrastructure. Customer manages OS and above. Provider manages hardware.

questions.question: A public cloud is characterized by:

options.A: Infrastructure owned and used by a single organization
options.B: Multi-tenant infrastructure available to the general public
options.C: Physical servers located on customer premises
options.D: Resources not shared between any customers

questions.explanation: Public clouds provide multi-tenant infrastructure shared among many customers, offered by providers like AWS, Azure, and Google Cloud. Resources are allocated on-demand with pay-as-you-go pricing. Economies of scale provide cost benefits.
questions.tip: Public cloud = shared, multi-tenant, pay-as-you-go. AWS, Azure, GCP.

questions.question: Software as a Service (SaaS) applications are:

options.A: Installed and managed on customer servers
options.B: Fully managed by the provider and accessed via web browser
options.C: Development platforms for building custom applications

questions.explanation: SaaS delivers complete applications via the internet, managed entirely by the provider. Customers access via browser without managing infrastructure, platform, or application code. Examples: Salesforce, Microsoft 365, Workday.
questions.tip: SaaS = ready-to-use applications. Provider manages everything. Browser access.

questions.question: A key advantage of cloud computing is:

options.B: Ability to scale resources up or down based on demand
options.C: Complete elimination of all security risks

questions.explanation: Cloud scalability allows rapid resource adjustment based on demand—adding capacity for peaks and reducing during lulls. This elasticity provides cost efficiency (pay for what you use) and agility compared to fixed on-premises capacity.
questions.tip: Scalability = adjust resources on demand. Elastic capacity, pay for use.

questions.question: A private cloud provides:

options.A: Resources shared with the general public
options.B: Dedicated infrastructure for a single organization

questions.explanation: Private clouds provide dedicated infrastructure for a single organization—either on-premises or hosted by a provider. This offers more control and may address compliance requirements but reduces economies of scale compared to public cloud.
questions.tip: Private cloud = single organization, dedicated resources. More control, less economy of scale.

questions.question: Platform as a Service (PaaS) provides:

options.B: Development platform with tools, runtime, and middleware for building applications

questions.explanation: PaaS provides a platform for developing and deploying applications—including runtime, middleware, development tools, and databases. Customers focus on code while the provider manages infrastructure and platform. Examples: Heroku, Google App Engine.
questions.tip: PaaS = development platform. Focus on code, not infrastructure. Provider manages platform.

questions.question: In the cloud shared responsibility model:

options.A: The cloud provider is responsible for all security
options.B: Security responsibilities are divided between provider and customer
options.C: Customers are responsible for all security
options.D: No party is responsible for security

questions.explanation: Shared responsibility divides security: providers secure the cloud infrastructure (physical, network, hypervisor), customers secure what they put in the cloud (data, access, applications). Specific divisions vary by service model (IaaS vs PaaS vs SaaS).
questions.tip: Provider: security OF the cloud. Customer: security IN the cloud.

questions.question: Identity and Access Management (IAM) in cloud environments is primarily the responsibility of:

options.B: The customer for their users and applications

questions.explanation: While providers offer IAM tools, customers are responsible for configuring access controls, managing users, implementing least privilege, and monitoring access. Poor IAM configuration is a leading cause of cloud security incidents.
questions.tip: IAM = customer responsibility. Misconfigurations cause many cloud breaches.

questions.question: A hybrid cloud environment combines:

options.B: Private cloud or on-premises with public cloud, with integration between them

questions.explanation: Hybrid cloud integrates private/on-premises infrastructure with public cloud, allowing workloads to move between them. Organizations can keep sensitive data private while leveraging public cloud for scalability and other workloads.
questions.tip: Hybrid = private + public, integrated. Flexibility to place workloads appropriately.

questions.question: Data residency requirements in cloud computing address:

options.B: Geographic location where data must be stored

questions.explanation: Data residency requirements specify where data must physically reside—often mandated by regulations (GDPR for EU data). Cloud regions and availability zones help organizations comply by selecting specific geographic locations for data storage.
questions.tip: Data residency = where data physically lives. Regulatory compliance requirement.

questions.question: For cloud data security, encryption should be applied:

options.B: Only to data in transit
options.C: To data at rest, in transit, and ideally in use
options.D: Encryption is not needed in cloud environments

questions.explanation: Comprehensive cloud security encrypts data at rest (stored), in transit (network transmission), and increasingly in use (processing). Customers should manage their own encryption keys when possible for maximum control.
questions.tip: Encrypt everywhere: at rest, in transit, in use. Control your own keys.

questions.question: Multi-tenancy in cloud computing creates risk because:

options.B: Multiple customers share underlying infrastructure

questions.explanation: Multi-tenancy means multiple customers share physical infrastructure (hypervisors, storage, networks). While providers implement strong isolation, potential risks include side-channel attacks, co-tenant attacks, and data leakage from misconfiguration.
questions.tip: Multi-tenancy = shared infrastructure. Rely on provider isolation. Encrypt sensitive data.

questions.question: Vendor lock-in risk in cloud computing can be mitigated by:

options.A: Using only one cloud provider for all services
options.B: Using portable technologies and avoiding proprietary services

questions.explanation: Vendor lock-in makes it difficult and expensive to switch providers. Mitigation includes: using open standards and portable technologies, containerization, multi-cloud strategies, avoiding deep reliance on proprietary services, and maintaining data portability.
questions.tip: Avoid lock-in: portable tech, containers, open standards, data export capabilities.

questions.question: A Cloud Access Security Broker (CASB) provides:

options.B: Visibility and control over cloud service usage and data

questions.explanation: CASBs sit between users and cloud services, providing visibility into cloud usage, data loss prevention, access control, threat protection, and compliance monitoring. They help organizations secure SaaS applications and enforce policies.
questions.tip: CASB = visibility + control over cloud services. DLP, access control, compliance.

questions.question: Cloud availability zones help organizations by:

options.B: Providing physically separate facilities for high availability and disaster recovery

questions.explanation: Availability zones are physically separate data centers within a region, with independent power, cooling, and networking. Deploying across zones provides high availability—if one zone fails, applications continue in others.
questions.tip: Availability zones = fault isolation. Deploy across zones for HA/DR.

questions.question: Cloud service level agreements (SLAs) typically define:

options.B: Availability guarantees, performance metrics, and remedies for non-compliance

questions.explanation: Cloud SLAs specify service commitments: uptime guarantees (e.g., 99.99%), performance metrics, response times for issues, and remedies (credits) if commitments aren't met. Customers should understand SLA terms and their limitations.
questions.tip: SLA = service commitments + remedies. Understand limitations and exclusions.

questions.question: Cloud misconfigurations are a leading security concern because:

options.A: Cloud providers don't offer security features
options.B: Default settings and complex options lead to insecure configurations
options.C: All cloud data is automatically public

questions.explanation: Cloud misconfigurations (public S3 buckets, exposed databases, excessive permissions) cause many breaches. Complex settings, permissive defaults, and rapid deployment without security review contribute. Automated configuration scanning helps detect issues.
questions.tip: Misconfiguration = #1 cloud risk. Review defaults, use scanning tools, least privilege.

questions.question: Serverless computing (FaaS) differs from traditional cloud by:

options.B: Executing code in response to events without managing servers

questions.explanation: Serverless (Functions as a Service) executes code in response to events (HTTP requests, file uploads) without customers managing servers. Providers handle scaling, patching, and availability. You pay only for execution time. Examples: AWS Lambda, Azure Functions.
questions.tip: Serverless = no server management. Event-driven, auto-scaling, pay per execution.

questions.question: Cloud Workload Protection Platforms (CWPP) provide security for:

options.B: Virtual machines, containers, and serverless workloads in cloud environments

questions.explanation: CWPPs protect cloud workloads—VMs, containers, serverless functions—providing vulnerability management, configuration compliance, runtime protection, and threat detection. They secure workloads across cloud environments.
questions.tip: CWPP = workload-level cloud security. VMs, containers, serverless protection.

questions.question: A cloud exit strategy should include:

options.A: Plans for data extraction and migration if changing providers
options.B: Only cost reduction measures

questions.explanation: Exit strategies plan for transitioning away from a cloud provider—data extraction, application migration, timeline, and cost. Important for managing vendor risk and ensuring business continuity if switching providers becomes necessary.
questions.tip: Exit strategy = plan B. Data portability, migration path, contractual rights.

questions.question: Container orchestration platforms like Kubernetes provide:

options.B: Automated deployment, scaling, and management of containerized applications

questions.explanation: Kubernetes automates container deployment, scaling (up/down based on demand), load balancing, self-healing (restart failed containers), and rolling updates. It manages complex containerized applications across clusters of hosts.
questions.tip: Kubernetes = container orchestration. Automates deployment, scaling, management.

questions.question: Cloud Security Posture Management (CSPM) tools help organizations by:

options.B: Continuously monitoring for misconfigurations and compliance violations

questions.explanation: CSPM tools continuously assess cloud environments for misconfigurations, compliance violations, and security risks. They automate detection of issues like public storage, excessive permissions, and missing encryption, enabling rapid remediation.
questions.tip: CSPM = continuous cloud security assessment. Find misconfigurations automatically.

questions.question: A multi-cloud strategy provides benefits including:

options.A: Simpler management and lower costs always
options.B: Reduced vendor lock-in and ability to select best-of-breed services

questions.explanation: Multi-cloud uses multiple providers strategically—reducing lock-in, enabling best-of-breed selection, and potentially improving resilience. Challenges include complexity, skill requirements, and governance across providers.
questions.tip: Multi-cloud: flexibility, reduced lock-in. But adds complexity and skill needs.

questions.question: Cloud-native security requires different approaches because:

options.A: Traditional security tools work identically in cloud
options.B: Dynamic, ephemeral resources require security that adapts to rapid changes

questions.explanation: Cloud-native environments are dynamic—resources spin up and down, IPs change, containers are ephemeral. Security must integrate with CI/CD, use APIs, operate at cloud scale, and adapt to rapid changes. Traditional perimeter approaches don't suffice.
questions.tip: Cloud-native = ephemeral, dynamic. Security must be API-driven, automated, adaptive.

questions.question: Infrastructure as Code (IaC) improves cloud security by:

options.B: Enabling version control, review, and consistent, repeatable deployments
options.C: Removing the need for access controls

questions.explanation: IaC defines infrastructure in code files that can be version controlled, reviewed before deployment, and consistently applied. Security configurations are codified, auditable, and repeatable—reducing drift and misconfiguration from manual changes.
questions.tip: IaC = infrastructure defined in code. Version control, review, consistency, auditability.

questions.question: FinOps (cloud financial management) practices include:

options.B: Real-time visibility, accountability, and optimization of cloud spending

questions.explanation: FinOps combines financial accountability with cloud operations—real-time cost visibility, team accountability for spend, right-sizing resources, using reservations/spot instances, and continuous optimization. It's essential as cloud costs can spiral without governance.
questions.tip: FinOps = cloud financial management. Visibility, accountability, optimization.

questions.question: Cloud secrets management solutions address the risk of:

options.B: Credentials and API keys exposed in code, configurations, or logs

questions.explanation: Secrets management (HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager) securely stores and manages credentials, API keys, certificates, and other secrets. They prevent secrets from being hardcoded, logged, or exposed—a common cause of cloud breaches.
questions.tip: Secrets management = centralized, secure credential storage. No hardcoding secrets.

questions.question: Cloud auto-scaling provides both benefits and risks because:

options.B: Automatic scaling improves availability but can lead to unexpected costs
options.D: Auto-scaling eliminates the need for monitoring

questions.explanation: Auto-scaling automatically adds resources for demand spikes (improving availability) and removes them when demand drops (saving costs). However, misconfigured scaling or attacks triggering scaling can create unexpected costs. Limits and alerts are essential.
questions.tip: Auto-scaling: Set limits, monitor costs. Attacks can trigger scaling and costs.

questions.question: Virtual Private Clouds (VPCs) enhance security by:

options.B: Providing isolated network segments with customizable security controls
options.C: Sharing networks with all cloud customers

questions.explanation: VPCs create isolated virtual networks within public cloud. Customers control IP ranges, subnets, routing, security groups, and network ACLs. VPCs can connect to on-premises via VPN or dedicated links while remaining isolated from other customers.
questions.tip: VPC = isolated virtual network. Control subnets, routing, security groups.

questions.question: When auditing cloud environments, auditors should:

options.A: Rely solely on provider certifications without additional testing
options.B: Evaluate customer responsibilities, configurations, and provider attestations

questions.explanation: Cloud audits must cover: provider certifications/attestations (SOC reports), customer configuration and controls, shared responsibility alignment, data protection, and cloud-specific risks. Provider certifications don't cover customer responsibilities.
questions.tip: Cloud audit: Provider attestations + customer controls + configuration review.

questions.question: Cloud logging services (CloudTrail, Azure Monitor) are essential for:

options.B: Security monitoring, incident investigation, and compliance evidence

questions.explanation: Cloud logging captures API calls, resource changes, access events, and activities. Essential for security monitoring (detect anomalies), incident investigation (forensics), compliance evidence, and troubleshooting. Enable and retain logs appropriately.
questions.tip: Cloud logging: Enable everywhere, retain appropriately, integrate with SIEM.

questions.question: A service mesh in cloud-native architectures provides:

options.B: Infrastructure layer for service-to-service communication, security, and observability

questions.explanation: Service meshes (Istio, Linkerd) handle service-to-service communication in microservices—providing traffic management, security (mTLS, authorization), and observability (tracing, metrics) without changing application code.
questions.tip: Service mesh = infrastructure for microservices communication. Security + observability.

questions.question: Customer-managed encryption keys (CMEK) in cloud provide:

options.B: Customer control over key lifecycle and the ability to revoke access

questions.explanation: CMEK gives customers control over encryption key lifecycle—creation, rotation, revocation. If you revoke the key, even the provider can't access data. This provides stronger control but requires key management responsibility.
questions.tip: CMEK = customer key control. Revoke key = data inaccessible. More control, more responsibility.

questions.question: FedRAMP (Federal Risk and Authorization Management Program) is:

options.B: A US government program for assessing and authorizing cloud services

questions.explanation: FedRAMP provides a standardized approach for security assessment, authorization, and monitoring of cloud services used by US federal agencies. FedRAMP authorization indicates the cloud service meets federal security requirements.
questions.tip: FedRAMP = US federal cloud security certification. Required for government use.

questions.question: Implementing Zero Trust in cloud environments requires:

options.B: Continuous verification, micro-segmentation, and identity-based access regardless of network location

questions.explanation: Cloud Zero Trust verifies every access request based on identity and context, regardless of whether it originates from inside or outside the cloud network. Micro-segmentation, strong identity, continuous verification, and least privilege are key principles.
questions.tip: Cloud Zero Trust: No implicit trust. Verify identity/context for every access.
